npm version [<newversion> | major | minor | patch | premajor | preminor | prepatch | prerelease [--preid=<prerelease-id>] | from-git]

'npm [-v | --version]' to print npm version
'npm view <pkg> version' to view a package's published version
'npm ls' to inspect current package/dependency versions

Run this in a package directory to bump the version and write the new
data back to

argument should be a valid semver string, a
valid second argument to

. In the second case,
the existing version will be incremented by 1 in the specified field.
will try to read the latest git tag, and use that as the new npm version.

If run in a git repo, it will also create a version commit and tag.
This behavior is controlled by

(see below), and can
be disabled on the command line by running

.
It will fail if the working directory is not clean, unless the

config option, npm will
use it as a commit message when creating a version commit. If the

then that will be replaced with the
resulting version number. For example:
npm version patch -m "Upgrade to %s for reasons"

config is set, then the tag will be signed using
the

flag to git. Note that you must have a default GPG key set up
in your git config for this to work properly. For example:

$ npm config set sign-git-tag true
$ npm version patch

in package.json

Again, scripts should explicitly add generated files to the commit using

script. Use it to clean up the file system or automatically push
the commit and/or tag.

"scripts": {
      "preversion": "npm test",
      "version": "npm run build && git add -A dist",
      "postversion": "git push && git push --tags && rm -rf build/temp"
    }
This runs all your tests, and proceeds only if they pass. Then runs your

script, and
adds everything in the

directory to the commit. After the commit, it pushes the new commit
and tag up to the server, and deletes the
